docs.lead_paragraph: About 1,000 of the state's sickest residents are on the verge of losing private health insurance because of a legal glitch in a process that was supposed to transfer their coverage from a longstanding Blue Cross policy to different health plans. These patients, with serious chronic conditions ranging from AIDS to hemophilia, have medical expenses running into tens of thousands of dollars a year, generally for drugs and home care. And many say that without insurance they will be bankrupt in months.

headline.main: 1,000 Patients Lose Insurance To a Loophole

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirteen big drug manufacturers are close to agreement on a huge cash settlement in a class action lawsuit brought by thousands of retail pharmacies, according to lawyers familiar with the case. The pharmacies have accused the drug makers of overcharging them in violation of Federal antitrust laws. The lawsuit, one of several parallel actions filed on behalf of pharmacy groups, contends that these and other drug makers conspired to charge the independents higher prices than they charged big buyers under managed health care drug plans.

headline.main: 13 Drug Makers Ready to Settle Pharmacist Suit

docs.lead_paragraph: Depression, which experts say is an often underdiagnosed and untreated mental disorder afflicting millions of Americans, has another overlooked dimension. The ailment is also an unrecognized complicating factor in other mental and physical illnesses, specialists say. More doctors are beginning to realize that undiagnosed depression can be not only an underlying component of substance abuse, eating disorders and other conditions, but also an unseen consequence of other seemingly unrelated diseases, and that it can seriously interfere withtreatment and rehabilitation.

headline.main: As Fellow Traveler of Other Illness, Depression Often Goes in Disguise

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today refused to hear a case challenging an exclusive patent that has prevented lower-cost, generic versions of the leading AIDS medication from entering the market. Without comment, the Justices turned down appeals filed by two generic-drug manufacturers that had challenged the validity of the patent on the medication, AZT. Since 1987, AZT has provided a profitable monopoly to the Burroughs Wellcome Company.

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Reject Challenge Of Patent for AIDS Drug
